comments.commentBody: The Diary of a Young Girl is a banned book? In my community, it was just about required reading for all of us, no matter where we went to school (public, day school, yeshiva).

That is why I am VERY skeptical about this "claim" --- that so many books are BANNED.

I think Dr. Klass here is exaggerating. Some parents may not choose these books and some schools may not stock them SCHOOL libraries, but I hardly think that counts as BANNING them.

I'd have loved more specific information -- who, precisely, has BANNED Anne Frank's Diary? Seriously! because every school I know has it on the required reading list -- and I worked for a public arts institution, which hosted an Anne Frank event that was attended by nearly every school district in the region!
Yeah, in some places it's banned and i think there are some abridged editions that remove some of Anne's sexual awakenings and awareness of her developing body.

The editions that remove some of the more frankly sexual passages of Anne's diary were curated by her father, who sought to preserve more of her privacy amidst what was already a very intimate and frank picture of a young woman's thoughts.

I was actually surprised that Shakespeare and the Tanakh weren't on the banned book list. I suspect that the Christian holy book(s) would be banned too if they weren't most of these people's theological underpinnings.

This is also a poker game being played by Trump and his cohorts. The power to essentially do-away-with ACA indeed- can be accomplished by a mere stop in defending the lawsuit: Eliminate the subsidies and the program WILL be destroyed. Trump and Crew (at least Ryan and Crew) are aware of this. They cannot do this because they have nothing to replace the ACA-with. Open enrollment just ended and folks have selected their plans.
Openly discussing withdrawing from this appeal- would be enough to cause an economic upheaval not just in the Insurance Markets, but also other markets impacted by health insurance access: Medical Equipment, Hospitals. Transport; Schools who've expanded training programs to accommodate the increase in Medical occupations. So many ancillary industries and occupations play a part in providing and facilitating health care; the sheer loss would be astounding:
Aside from sheer malice of intent- Ryan and gang aren't stupid. They know what the stakes are, and are not ready to take the fall- if disruption comes too soon.

Of course. Get used to it, Americans: we have just elected a con man,
who cannot resist working the suckers as long as he can.
Indeed.  And he found many, many "marks" that suckered into his game.

Bruni, As good as this is, it is out of date.  It just took a few hours for the women, men, children and babies of America to put Trump in his place as no writer could do. This is the Day that lifted the spirits of the American people.  Women haven't been corrupted as many men haven't either, but it took women of all ages to remind America of what it's about.  Women may have known most clearly the danger of Trump, the unacceptable Trump, and they came out of their doors with the knowledge that it is up to us to protect each other. We reinforced one another as we quietly took to the streets of America.  It was unexpected that a Trump presidency and Republican control of the levers of power would revitalize our country. It was unexpected that millions of us around the world would march today.  Will the Democratic Party get its act together? There are many questions about how we will proceed. While there is much to do, 'Yes, we can!'

Putin must have a lot of confidence in his ability to control Trump
considering that he helped put a man into the Presidency who could saturate Russia with doomsday weapons.

Just a thought -- but "Deep Blue" beat the world's best chess player, the best go master, and the best Jeopardy players. Might a final test be to run the country?

Herr Gropenfurher will not be deterred from his self delusions. Sociopaths never are, they are self deceivers, they believe their own exaggerations, they expect others to do so also.

all we can do is target those GOP legislators that let him indulge in his fantasy world. As for Rand, she was right when she said changes in philosophy and ides take 50-100 years. She has been dismissed as a crank, but these people are characters in her books, she saw them coming and they are not her heroic ones, the are scurrilous ones, but the see themselves as the leaders. Trump is very much like her anti hero, James Taggert, a braggart, a poltroon, a coward.

We can set him on a path to self destruction by constantly making fun of him, putting his pseudo self esteem in the spotlight as being that of a mentally disturbed nothing, letting him know the public detests him. people who can not laugh, are mental midgets.

I read this column in total disbelief. The world's only superpower has just elected a man who is totally unfit for the office, who ran a campaign filled with hatred targeted at Hispanics, Muslims, immigrants, and mocked the disabled and takes pride in his disgraceful treatment of and behavior towards women. He makes threats about silencing the press, internet, and television media that dares to criticize him and he just gave an inaugural address where he pointedly did not call for unity.

In Poland and Hungary far wing wing governments have taken over with anti semitism rearing its ugly head with dark similarities to the 1930's. France might soon elect a far right extremist, and Britain is pulling out of the European Union in large part due to the flow of immigration from the Middle East.

In Syria nearly one million people have been killed and the dictator continues to use chemical weapons against his own people and no one seems willing to stop him.

The Iranians have armed the terrorist group Hezbollah with more than 100,000 missiles targeted at Israeli cities, the government of Israel moves further right and our new President seeks to increase the chances of war between Israel and Iran which Israel's prime minister seems to welcome.

China and America could be involved in a disastrous trade war, and Russia continues to wreak havoc on the world order with apparent help from our new President and is now trying to topple Angela Merkel.

And this may be the best year ever???

While all your points are well-taken, remember that Nick is talking specifically how, for so many people who aren't in the developed technical world, the little things that make a difference between life or death, have gotten better. Not all will live, not all will elude disease, not all will be educated, but more will, and fewer will suffer.

As for the rest, I look at it with as much dread as you do.

Yes, it might be. Mr. Kristof's criteria are far different than those you offer. Yours seem to be media headlines sorted by popularity, intended to inflame passions. Kristof's are those human activities which help people directly, seeking no fanfare.
I hope Mr. K is correct.

Great points which have absolutely nothing to do with the plight of 90% of the world's poor. Immigration was never going to fix global poverty. The fixes must occur in the poor countries and on that note results have in fact been amazing.

By the way the Poland election shift to the far right was triggered by illegal wiretaps that caught liberal politicians making very unflattering comments. Sound familiar??

By that theory, they are gambling with their credibility, hoping it comes out "right" meaning wrong for all of us, so they can say "I told you so" about things they predicted before they could know.

That is not even a claim to credibility after they get lucky.

We need better from the press. Go as far as the evidence takes them, but not further. Don't fear to say what is there, but don't go for speculation as fact, or rumors not chased down.

Here is the gist of a comment I made on this column several hours ago.

I think Ross's miss givings are misplaced.I don't think journalists are in danger of falling into a trump imitation game. But they ARE in danger of getting sidelined and trapped by a master manipulator.

At this point it's game on. Serious journalists will take to heart the fiasco that occurred in trumps first press conference when he had them off balance, dancing while simultaneously insulting them. It was a very poor show.

Unless reputable news media band together and cooperate instead of competing, they will always be on the ropes once Trump has a chance and the time to paint a story. Jim Rutenberg describes their dilemma in the Mediator column of two weeks ago.

The man is dangerous. Journalists underestimate him at their peril. But if ever there was a time when we need the press to hold this man accountable, it's now.

Both sides need each other. Trump wants coverage, and the media want to be first to market with the story. There's a fine line between caution and impulse in the publication game.

But I trust that if reputable media simply do their jobs and follow their internal processes, it should be easier for them to be able to cover Trump honestly and forthrightly.

Goodness, Mr. Kristof, you're quite the pollyanna! I congratulate you for your optimism; it's a thousand pities I can't share it.

Global poverty and children's health and lives are, as you note some way down in your essay, not very high on the agenda of the new administration. Just yesterday, in his inaugural address, the new president said "America first!" How does this defiant manifesto of jingoism (delivered in anger with a closed fist) translate into a concern for suffering children anywhere? The new president was more taken with his new hotel in Washington where, surely, the great unwashed would be turned away.

Private American philanthropy aside, Mr. Kristof, the State Department is the agency that is on the front line of international humanitarian aid. The Department of Health and Human Services should be endowed with funds enough for the research and development of medicines that can combat blindness, e.g., not only overseas, but in our very land.

American citizens suffer from these societal ravages. What of the Zika virus? The right-wing Congress refused President Obama's reasonable request for money to combat the virus just last year. Do you think that a Trump administration, interested solely in abolishing the inheritance tax and deregulation of industry and commerce, cares at all about suffering people, whether they are Americans or not?

One can pray that your optimism may be well-grounded, Mr. Kristof. As of yesterday, I have no hope. None.

In Trump's mind, the U.S. is falling apart: carnage, crime, drugs, school kids not learning.

Why do some Americans let him get away with this garbage? It won't be long before he imposes protectionism( also mentioned in yesterday's speech) and his supporters suddenly find Wal Mart prices skyrocketing, airline fares escalating because Boeing can't sell their planes and BMW workers in South Carolina are laid off.
Thank you so much for helping us to get perspective! We need to be hearing and reading more news like your columns and not just the latest thing that Mr. Trump has done.
Thank you for this column.  It helps.

Yes, everything is as terrible as it seems. When it is being reported that Trump has stated he will use Iraq's oil to pay for Americans' social programs. When he has the founder of Blackwater as a close adviser. When Trump makes messianic comments in his inaugural speech -- a few days after Putin applauded him for not being messianic. When an incoming president shakes his fist during his first address to the nation as president -- to mention but the first few things that come to mind. Why then, yes, things are terrible as they seem and then some. But a brighter view is very welcome.

Why does everyone, including the NYT, continue to dance around the graveyard? The United States is *over*. There is *no* path to recovery. Please, take your hands off your chests and LOOK and LISTEN.!

Dear Polly Anna: You're considering only ONE species: Homo sapiens (sic).
An estimated 30,000 plants and animals are driven extinct annually, almost all caused by human impacts, not normal evolution. Humans are the most destructive (and only SELF-destructive) species on the planet, to the detriment of all other life forms. "Wise"? Hardly. "Clever," certainly.
Key to all these issues, of course, is gross human overpopulation, which almost NOBODY addresses, fearful of losing funding, no doubt.
RECOMMENDED READING: Alan Weisman's "COUNTDOWN."
With the Trump ascendancy, America, democracy and the world at large are entering Dark Times, indeed. Cry, the Beloved Country.

Yes, fine, and say that loud and clear.

Don't go past to speculation. Don't spread fears as facts. Stick to facts. They'll be bad enough soon enough, if you're right.

In the meantime, we need clear news, not partisanship as news. That is just fake news from yet another side.

The penalties for avoiding enrollment in an insurance plan should have probably been a good deal heftier than the ones that were finally imposed.  Universal health care is the law in virtually every country in the industrialized world, and in virtually every country the costs are far lower than they are in ours.  Too bad that in this instance we truly are an "exceptional" nation.
Trump only got about 26% of the vote among eligible voters, so even the percentage of white women who voted for him is small. At today's March in San Francisco, almost a third or more were men.
Why would he remove women's right to vote?  Over 50% of white women, and 42% of women in general, voted FOR Trump.
no exclusion here --sf rally thanked male supporters with great enthusiasm.  This march was at least 40% men.
Donald Trump is the establishment now.
Big deal.  Just like the harassment of the Electoral College: a waste of time.  You just blew an election.  Keep it up, please.
Yeah, I couldn't believe still marching about this 40 years later....
